intro: Anagallis caerulea var. verticillata, commonly known as the spiral pink, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is a low-growing annual herb that typically reaches a height of 10–30 centimeters. The plant features wiry stems that often coil around other vegetation, and its leaves are opposite, ovate, and slightly hairy. Its flowers are small, pink or purple, and arranged in a whorled pattern along the stem, giving it its common name. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in meadows, roadsides, and waste areas.
